issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: All attempts at reproducing this issue failed, or not enough information was available to reproduce the issue. Reading the code produces no clues as to why this behavior would occur. If more information appears later, please reopen the issue.
resolution.name: Cannot Reproduce

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

comments.body:
A simple HTTPS api call against the UFS works just fine using euca2ools (DescribeImages)

Not sure why the Eucalyptus management console is not able to make same type of API call against HTTPS endpoint ??

Nothing really comes to mind. Here's what I observe (in case it helps).
It looks like authorization succeeded (though I don't see it in the log) because the failure is in the login after auth where we try to fetch account attributes.
It looks like the right host/port are being used. It looks like the service path is set right "/services/compute/".
FWIW, the auth call doesn't use boto, but the call that fails does (as does the rest of the app).

[~dshekhawat]: The console.ini looks pretty much the same as the default (at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/blob/master/conf/console.default.ini) except for the connection.debug setting.  Does login fail when connection.debug = false ?

Hi [~kgill], Its strange that everything is working fine now after I set the connection.debug = false. Earlier it was giving me the same result. I am not sure if the console relies on a network configuration to be loaded. In the case of failure I had not configured the network.json.

Sounds good to me. Thank you

Sent from a mobile device

I can confirm that in order to reproduce this issue (I reproduced this twice in lab) you need to have a cloud without a network.json configured. Usually that can happen when you are installing a new cloud and before configuring the network try to access the user console. This access will fail in a very weird way suggesting something is wrong but not giving any further details. The root cause is that network.json is not configured. Perhaps a user friendly log message or something similar could be beneficial.
I encountered this during the DixonsCPW production install, some feedback that the network.json file is missing would assist with troubleshooting (Even in the logs)

[~dmccue], Deependra suggested a helpful log message would go a long way here. Help me understand more. Isn't the network.json file part of normal configuration for Edge mode? In what situations is that not present? Would using the cloud before the networking is fully configured be normal?
What type of error does the console report in this case? If we show "No response from host" as we do when we cannot reach the CLC, that would seem appropriate.

During the dixons install, we still havn't got the floating IP address range and so can't construct the network.json file.  I installed all the components and ran through the testing when I encountered that issue.  There's no feedback in any of the logs that the reason for the timeout is due to a missing network.json file.  That's not something you'd ever expect as being the root cause considering all tcp ports are open and responding on clc/cc/ufs etc...
A simple log message hinting at this in the eucaconsole.log file would have saved 2-3 hours of testing followed by searching for what it could be.

My big question is, since the console has no idea why it can't reach the CLC, should we mention the network.json file anyway?
What wasn't explained, is the cloud expected to be functional without the network.json configured? If that isn't configured and we expect some things to work, what still isn't working?
